description: From Middle English aware, iwar, iware, ywar, from Old English ġewær (“aware”), from Proto-West Germanic *gawar, from Proto-Germanic *waraz (“aware, cautious”), from Proto-Indo-European *worós (“attentive”), from *wer- (“to heed; watch out”). Cognate with Dutch gewaar, German gewahr, Swedish var, Icelandic varr.

adjectives.description: aware (comparative more aware or awarer, superlative most aware or awarest)

entries.meaning: Vigilant or on one's guard against danger or difficulty.
examples: Stay aware! Don't let your guard down.

entries.meaning: Conscious or having knowledge of something.
examples: Are you aware of what is being said about you?
